content: Solved and approved. I agree with JBM, it was a bit tedious. I literally kept falling asleep. :-) Then again, I'm tired. Still, I think it's a worthy puzzle. Thanks for the contribution, Nicola.

I want this!  I want this so bad.  A harder version of this puzzle could be you're given all the sides and have to figure out what the colors will be given some moves after for all sides.

That said, I think it would be better if you separated your commands with spaces, replaced the - with the industry standard ', and dropped the dots entirely.  Human readability in this case matters insofar as understanding how to make the code interpret it.  Also, the dots don't actually make it more readable.  New lines would, but they would complicate the code.

I like Magic Cube!
But I think you may describe the input format more clear. Like, whether word like "F3", "F4", "F11" or "F-2" "F-12" are permitted.  And you may add a long example which include all rules.

As an independent comment, notation.

French: http://www.francocube.com/notation
English: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rubik's_Cube#Move_notation

It's not the right notation because it's the oldest (it's probably not, it may be from the eighties but there *have* been publications before that), it's the Right one because the cubing world has converged, it's been normalized by the WCA in 2004, it was in dominant use for a few years before, and nobody in the know produces or consumes anything else since then. Any web search hit you could think of for cube timers, solvers or widgets online use it.

For example, the last validator: http://tinyurl.com/ja93jcl

Please change minus signs to primes (approximated in ASCII by apostrophes).
Solved it. Can't say it's particularly tedious. My solution is 125 lines in C++, all clean, without any convolutedness.

My comments as a coder:
- ugh. I can only think of tedious ways to solve this. I probably won't enjoy solving it once, let alone repeatedly.
- The dots complicate a complicated-enough-already problem for no good reason. Please drop them.

My comments as a speedcuber:
- yay, cubes!
- why not go for standard notation and habits? (primes/apostrophes instead of minus; focus on top "U" face instead of front)
- the 2x2x2 is usually referred to as the "Pocket Cube", not the "Mini Rubik".

The dots are just dropped when you preprocess the moves. That’s the way I transform - and 2 in a simple sequence of UDFBRL.
It’s not so tedious if you have the right structure. It’s not the 3×3×3 cube.
About - instead of ', it’s just a notation I use and find in books too. The moderators are free to change it.

What can I say, we don't have the same standards for tediousness. For POV reference, my current worst linecount is haunted manor at 100 (I could probably shave the 20 lines of "verification" code now it works), barnyard at 56 (because parsing).

This one looks like it's going to be 6 lines of state initialization (that's a lot of \n), 6 times 3 painfully induced orbits, and 2.5 lines of applying the permutations.

Nothing convoluted. But no point in automating the permutations' definition on such a small group. Hence the tediousness.

(note that it *is* a lot better than when we initially discussed it, since as a community puzzle I'll only need to solve it once)

So I'll solve it when (if) it gets approved. I won't enjoy it. I'll probably just copy-paste the perms from an online source.
Done, these moves won’t be given.

Looks like you haven't analyzed the problem enough then. I only have 4 rotations of different kinds, everything else is trivial stuff like TurnRight(){TurnLeft();TurnLeft();TurnLeft();}
I agree it's beside the point though.

I'm afraid I know the problem inside out, and you're kind of making my point. There are six basic moves (UFRLBD). Double and reverse are trivially implemented by repetition. (seems to be your example implementing Right in terms of Left) (there are other ways, but come one, srlsy) You can choose whether to implement all six, or only three and symmetry, or only two and rotation (srlsy), or only one and the whole shebang. My point is: the basic case (in my world) is tedious, and any simplification thereupon tends to win so little because 2x2x2 that actually taking the time to decide what the right level of simplification is will likely feel like a net loss in the end.

(I am fully aware of the irony of the fact I've now spent more time raising tediousness alarms than I'd need to solve. For better or worse, now it's been split away from the clash candidate set, it's not a puzzle that warrants deletion anymore)

You got a debate, what's not to like? ^^
Yep, I only have 3 top-level methods: 1 for turning the front half of the cube (the most complex, like in 3 method calls, spread over 10 lines just because I chose too long names for the arguments), 2 for rotating the whole cube around different axes. i didn't think too hard about data structure choice, but the idea is f course, to make it as easy as possible  for the 3 rotations I had to implement.
Everything else is constructed from combinations of those. From my POV it doesn't look more verbose than an average puzzle... well, it does look too large for CoC, I see your point there.
I'm afraid we don't have the same standards for tediousness.

I totally agree on the fact that is the choice of the data structure that is interesting here!
I don't understand the use of dots, but nevermind...
I stand by my accusation of tediousness. I'll add a bet: you too will be tempted to store the code for later copy-pasting once you've solved it once.
Not my philosophy... And every other clash could be solved like that.

I make a difference between a clash that can be solved by copypasting (as you said: all are) and a clash that I'd rather solve by copy-pasting than go through the tediousness *again*.
YMMV.
That's why I don't play CoC, because I know that I will paste my previously found answers (for all the clashes, not only the tedious ones).
Now it’s a puzzle, not a CoC.
